    >           Course Detail                                        The Music of Poetry and the Poetry of Music                                Semester and Year        FA 2015                    Course Number        IDSEM-UG1649                    Section        001                    Instructor        Lisa Goldfarb                    Days                            Tue,Thu                                 Time                            3:30 PM -       4:45 PM                                Units        4.0                    Level        U                    Foundation Requirement        HUM                                           Description       Although the ancient Greeks used the word “moûsike” to designate both poetry and music and the two were once “one” art, with alphabetic writing their paths diverged and poetry, music, rhetoric, and musical theory became distinct from one another. Yet, however much music and poetry may have their separate histories and technical languages, poets and composers have continued to probe the relation between the two arts. In this course, we will focus on the relationship between music and poetry in the modern era—from the “fin de siècle” and Verlaine’s call to the symbolist poets to compose “Music above everything,” to the modernists in English and American poetry and the jazz improvisations of the twentieth century. We will study musical and poetic history of the period, grapple with what we mean when we say a poem is musical and what melody means in poetry, and we will study how to define and discuss lyricism in music. Readings may include the work of modern poets (symbolists, imagists, modernists)—Mallarmé, Verlaine, Valéry, Pound, Auden, Mina Loy, Gertrude Stein, Langston Hughes, Stevens —and modern composers Debussy, Stravinsky, Copland, Ives, Thomson and the rhythms of blues and jazz. To develop a critical vocabulary, readings may also include texts on the history and theory of both arts (Winn, Bucknell, Kramer, Hollander, Meyer, Adorno).    Faculty          >           Lisa Goldfarb                               Lisa Goldfarb                                                           Associate Professor      B.A. Literature, SUNY Purchase, 1976 M.Phil. Comparative Literature,, CUNY Graduate Center, 1985 Ph.D. Comparative Literature,, CUNY Graduate Center, 1991           Lisa Goldfarb's research and teaching interests are in the fields of comparative literature (French and English) and critical writing. She focuses on 19th- and 20th-century European and American literature, and is particularly interested in modern poetry and poetics, the relationship between music and poetry, philosophic questions in literature, as well as the literature and history of New York City. Her interdisciplinary seminars on related themes include "Belief and Skepticism", "Sound and Sense", "Reading Poetry", "Wallace Stevens and the 20th Century", "Modern Poetry and the Actual World", and “The Music of Poetry and the Poetry of Music”. Professor Goldfarb has taught a foreign study course in Nîmes (France) and has accompanied student travel and study groups to Cuba, Prague, Athens, and Ireland. She is a recipient of Gallatin's Adviser of Distinction Award and NYU's Great Teacher Award. Her book,  The Figure Concealed: Wallace Stevens, Music, and Valéryan Echoes  , focuses on the resonance of Paul Valéry’s musical poetics in the poetry and prose of Wallace Stevens. In addition to her many journal articles on modern poetry, she is co-editor, with Bart Eeckhout, of a volume of essays,  Wallace Stevens, New York, and Modernism  (Routledge, 2012), which considers the impact of New York on the life and work of Wallace Stevens. Professor Goldfarb is president of the Wallace Stevens Society and associate editor of  The Wallace Stevens Journal  . Professor Goldfarb served as Associate Dean of Faculty and Academic Affairs from 2007 to 2014.                News       Professor Lisa Goldfarb edited (with Bart Eeckhout and Natalie Gerber) Helen Vendler’s Wallace Stevens , a special issue of The Wallace Stevens Journal (Johns Hopkins University Press, Fall 2014). Professor Goldfarb co-wrote the introduction, “Fifteen Ways of Looking at Helen Vendler’s Wallace Stevens” and her essay, “My Invisible Teacher: Helen Vendler on Wallace Stevens” appears in the same issue.   Professor Goldfarb was chosen to be a visiting researcher at the Sorbonne (University of Paris, 4) over the course of this year (2014-2015), and will be a GRI faculty fellow at NYU’s Paris site for a period of time during the spring semester.   Professor Goldfarb is organizing with colleagues from the Sorbonne and University of Antwerp a Spring 2015 conference, “Wallace Stevens in France: An International Conference.” She will present a paper, “Thinking through the Senses: Stevens, Valéry, and Proust.”   Professor Goldfarb and Bart Eeckhout were editors of a special issue of The Wallace Stevens Journal , entitled Wallace Stevens and W.H. Auden , published by Johns Hopkins University Press in 2013. Goldfarb contributed her article “‘An Unalterable Vibration’ or ‘An Altering Speech for Altering Things’: Stevens, Auden, and Symbolist Poetics” and co-wrote, with Bart Eeckhout, the introduction, “Stevens and Auden: Disparities and Affinities” to the special issue. She and Bart Eeckhout co-chaired and moderated a session on “Helen Vendler’s Wallace Stevens” at the 2014 MLA convention in January.     Professor Goldfarb’s essay “‘Thinking-Intuitive Types:’ Poetic Affinities in W.H. Auden and Paul Valéry’” was accepted for publication as a chapter for Auden at Work , a volume of essays edited by Bonnie Costello and Rachel Galvin (Palgrave MacMillan, forthcoming 2015). She co-organized the May 2014 international conference at the University of Antwerp, “Poetry after Wallace Stevens,” and will deliver the paper, “‘The Huge High Harmony:” Wallace Stevens’ Musical Legacy.’”                           top of page                                     Contact Information     Lisa Goldfarb             Associate Professor              lg3@nyu.edu             1 Wash Pl, Room 407             (212) 998-9152      Download as vCard                       Office Hours         Monday Sabbatical             Tuesday Sabbatical             Wednesday Sabbatical             Thursday Sabbatical               Friday Sabbatical                                                Courses                                                   2015             Fall                            The Music of Poetry and the Poetry of Music                  Tue,Thu      3:30 PM -      4:45 PM                                    Modern Poetry and the Actual World                  Tue,Thu      11:00 AM -      12:15 PM                                                   2014             Spring                            Reading Poetry                  Tue,Thu      3:30 PM -      4:45 PM                                                   2013             Fall                            The Music of Poetry and the Poetry of Music                  Tue,Thu      3:30 PM -      4:45 PM                                                   2012             Fall                            Modern Poetry and the Actual World                  Tue,Thu      3:30 PM -      4:45 PM                                       Research and Teaching Interests       19th- and 20th-century European and American poetry and fiction; Spring 2014 Graduate Courses    | Department of Music | NYU                                    New York University       Arts and Science       College of Arts and Science       Graduate School of Arts and Science                                    Back to  previous page                            Spring 2014 Graduate Courses Collegium Musicum - MUSIC-GA 1002 (2 credits)    Friday Time TBA (Silver 220)    Instructor: Margaret Panofsky    Students receive weekly private viol lessons, the time arranged with the professor. When proficient, they play in a viol ensemble. The FAS Music Department lends students a viol and bow from its collection. Qualified students may play with The Teares of the Muses, an ensemble affiliated with the NYU Music Department. The group performs on- and off-campus. Requirements to enroll in the course are previous vocal or instrumental training on any instrument - not limited to strings - and good musicianship skills. * Please note that the class will not actually take place within a structured course time. You will set up appointments for lessons with the professor.    Techniques of Music Composition - MUSIC-GA 2162    Tuesday 12:30-2:30    Instructor: Elizabeth Hoffman (section 001)    Instructor: Jaime Oliver (section 002) *Contact the instructor directly for lesson schedules.    Students meet individually with a selected faculty member frequently throughout the semester, to review and discuss their ongoing creative work. All students enrolled in this course must also participate a bi-weekly seminar, led by rotating faculty, that will encompass discussions of technical, aesthetic, and theoretical issues related to 20th/21st century composition. These seminars may also include talks or masterclasses by guests actively involved in the creation or performance of music.   Studies in 20th-Century Analysis - MUSIC-GA 2163    Thursday 10:30-12:30    Instructor: Louis Karchin Focus: Kaija Saariaho and Beat   Furrer. The course will begin with a brief survey of contemporary   analytic techniques, including consideration of reductive analysis   (Schenker, Lerdahl), atonal transformational models (Schoenberg, Forte,   Babbitt), contour theory (Reti, Marvin), semiotic analysis (Nattiez),   and hermeneutic models and processes (Kramer). After this introduction,   the focus will turn to the music of two composers whose works have   emerged as seminal in the 21st century: Kaija Saariaho and Beat Furrer.    Along with their compositions, the course will explore trends of the   latter 20th century that helped shape the aesthetics of these two   composes.   Special Studies: Musical Instruments and Technology - MUSIC-GA 2198 (section 001)  Friday 2:00-4:00    Instructor: Emily Dolan "Neither the bare hand nor the understanding left to itself are of much use. It is by instruments and other aids that the work gets done, and these are needed as much by the understanding as by the hand." - Francis Bacon, The Novum Organum (1620) This seminar explores the history of musical instruments and the diverse ways in which we can think about what they are and what they do. Among our themes, we will consider the origins of organology, the relationship between music and technology, the history of mediation, the digital, and instrumental interfaces. We will draw on texts from musicology, ethnomusicology, organology, media studies, sound studies, and the history of science. Instruments, machines, and technology occupy an increasingly central position within musical scholarship, and so we will also ponder this "instrumental turn," that status of instruments as objects of inquiry, and roles they play as boundary objects in various disciplines.  Special Studies: Musical Modernities, Modernisms, and Avant-Gardes - MUSIC-GA 2198 (section 002)  Thursday 2:00-4:00    Instructor: Brigid Cohen This course explores theories and historiographies of modernity, modernism, and the avant-garde, with a special focus on musical literatures, communities, and historical episodes from the 19th century to the present. In doing so, the course provides a critical introduction to the sharp contestations surrounding three interrelated concepts that have long wielded leverage in humanities scholarship. In addition to reading foundational texts that use and define these terms, we will also study contemporary debates that question whether these concepts - rooted in European intellectual histories - have purchase in the study of global comparative contexts. We will also contextualize our study within a network of related, contested key terms, ideas, and conditions: colonialism, capitalism, industrialization, nationality, technology, urbanization, revolution, and community. Theoretical discussions will be enriched by the study of specific artistic communities and settings, including 19th-century Parisian avant-gardes, the Ballets Russes, the Harlem Renaissance, the N é gritude movement, the 1930's ethnographic research community in Bali, agitprop theater, and late 20th-century avant-gardes in North America, Europe, and East Asia.  Special Studies: Russian Guitar Poetry and the Aesthetics of Attenuation - MUSIC-GA 2199 (section 001)  Tuesday 2:00-4:00    Instructor: J. Martin Daughtry This seminar, which is cross-listed in the Department of Russian and Slavic Studies, offers a broad exploration of avtorskaia pesnia (literally "author's song," but often glossed as "guitar poetry"), a musical practice that had its first efflorescence in the post-Stalinist Soviet Union and persists in an attenuated form throughout the contemporary Russian-speaking world. The seminar will deal with three broad timespaces: (1) the Soviet Union of the 1970s , when guitar poetry occupied a murky semi-official stance, its social salience was at its peak, and unofficial recordings were circulating wildly throughout the country; (2) Russia of the 1990s , where a new zeitgeist and economic reality forced an attenuation of its social salience, practitioners were forced to enter a commercial market where they were competing with foreign and domestic popular music, and attempts were made to adapt guitar poetry to the demands of Russian nationalism; and (3) the contemporary Russian diaspora , where the genre serves as a form of "reflective nostalgia" (Boym 2001); an organizing principle for disparate taste communities; and a modest but viable source of income for touring musicians. Over the course of the semester we will be doing a lot of listening and a fair amount of singing. I will also be bringing a number of practitioners into the classroom, and the class will be invited (though not required) to attend a number of events in the New York area. Russian fluency is not required, but some experience with the Russian language is desirable. (Ideally, students should be able to translate Russian lyrics with the aid of a dictionary).  Special Studies: The Ethics of Musical Marginality in the 20th Century - MUSIC-GA 2199 (section 002)  Tuesday 5:00-7:00    Instructor: David Samuels The twentieth century was witness to an ethical discourse about the scope of human that took its cues from a discussion of how human beings should sound, and how people should respond to sound. Specifically, the tones and timbres of vocal and instrumental music acted as a key locus of a dialogue about how one could maintain one's humanity under the conditions of modern urban industrial capital. This course will approach folk revivalism, knowledge of world musics, and practices of early music performance as three emergent and overlapping responses to the perceived dehumanizing processes of the twentieth century. Central to all three are arguments about the human body and shared social participation that place questions of sonorous practice at the center of a conversation about how one expresses one's ethical humanity in the contemporary world, and vice versa.  Special Studies: Ethnographies of Global Popular Music - MUSIC-GA 2199 (section 003)  Monday 4:00-6:00    Instructor: Lauren Ninoshvili How are the musical dimensions of globalization experienced on the ground, in the sorts of geographically bounded areas that have traditionally served as sites of engaged ethnographic inquiry? This course seeks to understand the variety of ways in which globally circulating musical styles impact local aesthetics and repertoires, as an antidote to the kinds of universalizing, "armchair" theorizations that have dominated scholarly discourse on music and globalization to date. Key issues to be addressed include cultural imperialism and resistance, ownership and appropriation, purity and hybridity, circulation, liveness and mediation. Focusing on ethnographic monographs published within the last decade, the course sets as a parallel goal a critical reflection on the art and craft of musical ethnography (as both research methodology and writing style) in this era of Internet-mediated cultural experience.
